item.title: By: Adam Ferziger
item.dc:creator: Adam Ferziger
item.description:
Alan,
As always thanks for calling attention to a provocative and thoughtful book. That said, after having read significant portions of the book I feel that Roy's expertise as an Islamicist with a personal and intellectual background in early modern Christianity are clear, whereas his grasp of contemporary Judaism is severely limited. Although his concept of de-territorialisation in offers an interesting framework for addressing Chabad's world-wide growth, it doesn't appreciate the fact that no matter where you stand on the Jewish religious spectrum the return to territoriality via Israel represents a key underpinning to numerous initiatives and reactions that have emerged in the last few decades. Moreover, territoriality accounts for a lot of what distinguishes Israeli religion - and foremost some of its fundamentalist elements - from Judaism in the Diaspora. The radical Eretz Yisrael movement is an obvious example. More nuanced, however, are the ways living in a Jewish welfare state has given non-Zionist groups the license to develop and behave in ways that they would never dream of if they were not in a sovereign environment.
All the best, Adam
